Award.AbstractNarration:
The Hodge conjecture is one of the central problems of algebraic geometry. If true, it would give a strong connection between topology and algebraic geometry. The integral Hodge conjecture is a stronger statement which fails for some algebraic varieties, as shown by Atiyah and Hirzebruch. Nonetheless, the project aims to prove the integral Hodge conjecture for a large class of 3-dimensional varieties. In another direction, the integral Hodge conjecture often fails for quotients of varieties by finite groups. The project will compute the Chow ring of algebraic cycles for quotient varieties by many finite groups. This can be viewed as finding the correct replacement for the integral Hodge conjecture when it fails.

Algebraic geometry is the study of shapes defined by polynomial equations. It is a central area of mathematics, at the border between arbitrary shapes (topology) and the theory of equations (algebra and computation). Users of mathematics have always had to solve systems of polynomial equations, and that remains a computationally challenging problem today. The project deals with the question of which shapes can be moved continuously to become defined by polynomial equations. There is a plausible answer, but a proof seems exceedingly hard to find. The project aims to solve the problem in the most important low-dimensional cases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many areas of science and engineering model physical phenomena using spaces defined by algebraic equations. The project introduced mathematical tools to describe the broad structure of the space defined by a given set of equations, where "broad" means that we simplify in a way that preserves information relevant to the particular questions under study. The resulting tools can be used for computation.

There is more than one way to think about the broad structure of a space. One approach (known as "topology") studies the holes in a space, including questions about whether a loop in the space can be shrunk to a point. The project used a different approach (called "birational geometry"), asking how much a space can be simplified by making suitable cuts.

Some spaces become very simple after making cuts. Think of a box that can be completely flattened after cutting it apart. For another example, a circle can be projected onto a line after removing one point. On the other hand, some spaces cannot be identified with flat space, no matter what cuts are made. In general, it is hard to determine which category a space falls into by looking at the defining algebraic equations.

The project made major progress on this question. We showed that the space defined by an algebraic equation that is complicated in a precise sense cannot be identified with flat space, no matter what cuts are made. This is typical of the way mathematics works: we want to solve a problem if that is possible, but if not, we want a guarantee that no solution exists.

A graduate student took part in the project, and two other students were inspired to begin research in the area of the project. The mathematical training they received, because it concentrates on fundamental structures and lasting theories, is among the strongest and most future-proof preparations for new developments in many areas of the economy.
